security: Disclosing details of Abram Chayes' security approval for liaison contact with J. Foster Collins and Archibald Roosevelt, Jr., regarding NSC 5412/2 matters, could reveal sensitive intelligence-gathering methods and contacts. Specifically, “Abram CHAYES...was granted Security approval for liaison contact with J. Foster COLLINS...on 6 March 1961. The request for CHAYES clearance was a 'Blanket' request to permit discussion with him of NSC 5412/2 matters on a need-to-know basis.” Additionally, revealing Samuel Wise's past application for CIA employment and subsequent contract work exposes potential intelligence sources and activities.
summary: This memo discusses Lee Harvey Oswald's return to the U.S. from the Soviet Union and details connections between Abram Chayes, Llewellyn Thompson, Samuel Wise, and the Oswald case, further exploring Chayes' security clearances and Wise's past with the CIA.
summary_one_paragraph: This memorandum, dated January 29, 1964, addresses the Lee Harvey Oswald case by examining the roles of Abram Chayes, Llewellyn Thompson, and Samuel Wise in Oswald’s return from the Soviet Union. It highlights Abram Chayes' security clearances, including liaison contact with J. Foster Collins and Archibald Roosevelt, Jr., for discussing NSC 5412/2 matters, and mentions a White House namecheck request on Chayes' wife. The memo also explores Samuel Wise’s potential involvement, referencing his past application for CIA employment, his work as a contract employee, and his connection to William Orville Munsell, who was disapproved for CIA employment due to questionable associations.
title: THE LEE HARVEY OSWALD CASE
